Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Design and Synthesis of New Lead-free Organometallic Halide Perovskite Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description. In recent years a new class of materials, called organometallic halide perovskite materials, has emerged with a potential to improve a solar cell's performance while fabricated at low cost. Concerned with the adverse effects to environment and health due to the use of lead in the existing perovskite materials, which can be dissolved in water, the research team aims to discover and develop new lead-free organometallic halide perovskite materials that are environmentally friendly and stable. The expected outcome of this project enables a sustainable solar cell technology that is safe for commercial deployment to generate low-cost solar electricity. The research team participates in multiple educational and outreach activities to recruit, train and mentor graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, particularly from underrepresented groups, who are interested in materials science and engineering. In addition, the project team intends to openly disseminate the computer codes used to design these materials and to predict their structures and properties.

Technical Description. The goal of this project is to use a computation-guided approach to study new lead-free organometallic halide perovskite materials with mixed metal ions. The lead-containing organometallic halide perovskite materials have shown great promise for offering superior optoelectronic properties to enable high performance photovoltaic action while allowing to be easily processed in solution or high vacuum. In this project, the research team seeks to replace the lead in these perovskite materials with ion pairs with the same or different valence states in specific ratios. The scientific tasks include: (1) computationally screening a large number of material candidates to identify promising candidates for further studies by employing high-throughput framework of MPInterfaces; (2) computational simulation of structure and properties of the identified candidates using density functional theory calculations; (3) solution-based synthesis of these perovskite materials in both thin film and bulk crystal forms; and (4) characterization of the electronic, optical, photovoltaic, and multiferroic behavior of these new perovskite materials. The ultimate goal is to explore the large family of lead-free, perovskite-structured organic-inorganic hybrid materials and to identify the most promising, environmentally-safe materials with improved performance for photovoltaics applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organometallic halide hybrid perovskite materials have emerged in recent years as a class of electronic materials with tremendous potentials for applications in various electronic and optoelectronic devices such as low-cost solar energy conversion and versatile lighting emitting devices. The objective of this project is to combine computational and experimental approaches to discover and develop new lead-free hybrid perovskite materials that are more environmentally friendly and stable than the existing lead-containing materials. Using high-throughput computation methods, we screened a huge number of potential lead-free hybrid perovskite candidates and examined their thermodynamic stability, from which viable candidates were further studied both computationally and experimentally. Additional computational studies revealed the detailed electronic properties of these compounds as well as the effect of the organic cation configurations on thermodynamic stability of the hybrid perovskite. Solution-based material synthesis techniques were further employed to grow single crystals for the viable candidates identified from computation. The crystal structure and composition of these crystals were carefully analyzed and compared to computation predictions. Among several new compounds discovered, a rubidium-bismuth containing double perovskite compound shows the most potential for electronic and/or optoelectronic applications as detailed characterization of the electronic and optical characteristics revealed that this lead-free hybrid perovskite single crystal has the same excellent charge transport properties as the existing lead-containing crystals while also being strongly absorptive in the visible spectrum. Significant results from this project has been disseminated to the research community in six peer-reviewed journal articles and two doctoral theses. The research team also participated in multiple educational and outreach activities to recruit, train and mentor graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, particularly from underrepresented groups, who are interested in materials science and engineering. The diverse research directions, especially the integration of computation and experimental work, provide a rich and profound environment for furthering the training and education of the four graduate and five undergraduate students involved in this project.
